concepts.concept_name: Electric charge, conservation of charge, and quantisation of charge
Coulomb's law: force between two point charges, superposition principle
Electric field: field due to a point charge, field lines, and field due to a dipole
Electric dipole: dipole moment, torque on a dipole in a uniform electric field
Gauss's theorem and its applications to find field due to infinitely long straight wire, uniformly charged infinite plane sheet, and uniformly charged thin spherical shell

in_scope: Frictional electricity, electric charge, properties of charge
Coulomb's law in vector form, force between multiple charges using superposition
Electric field intensity due to a point charge and system of charges
Electric field lines and their properties
Electric dipole moment (p = q × 2a), field on axial and equatorial positions
Torque on a dipole: τ = p × E
Electric flux, Gauss's law statement and proof
Applications of Gauss's law: infinite line charge, infinite plane sheet, spherical shell
out_of_scope: Derivation of Coulomb's law from Gauss's law (beyond NCERT scope)
Continuous charge distributions beyond NCERT examples
Electric field inside a conductor in detail (Class 12 level only uses Gauss's law results)
Advanced multipole expansions

concepts.concept_name: Electrostatic potential: potential due to a point charge, dipole, and system of charges; equipotential surfaces
Potential energy of a system of charges and of a dipole in an external field
Relation between electric field and potential; conductors and electric fields
Capacitors: parallel plate capacitor, capacitance, series and parallel combinations
Effect of dielectric on capacitance, energy stored in a capacitor

in_scope: Potential due to point charge: V = kq/r
Potential due to an electric dipole on axial and equatorial points
Potential due to a system of charges (superposition)
Equipotential surfaces and their properties
Relation between E and V: E = -dV/dr
Potential energy of a system of two or more point charges
Potential energy of a dipole in uniform external field: U = -p·E
Parallel plate capacitor derivation: C = ε₀A/d
Capacitors in series (1/C = 1/C₁ + 1/C₂) and parallel (C = C₁ + C₂)
Dielectric constant and effect on capacitance: C' = KC
Energy stored: U = ½CV² = ½QV = Q²/2C
out_of_scope: Laplace's and Poisson's equations (university level)
Method of images (beyond NCERT scope)
Spherical and cylindrical capacitors (beyond NCERT scope for CBSE)
Detailed dielectric polarisation theory

concepts.concept_name: Electric current, drift velocity, Ohm's law, and electrical resistance; V-I characteristics
Resistivity, temperature dependence of resistance, colour code of resistors, series and parallel combinations
EMF and internal resistance of a cell, Kirchhoff's rules and their applications (Wheatstone bridge)
Meter bridge and potentiometer: principle and applications (comparing EMFs, finding internal resistance)

in_scope: Flow of electric charge, current I = dQ/dt
Drift velocity: v_d = eEτ/m and relation I = nAv_d
Ohm's law: V = IR, resistance R = ρl/A
V-I characteristics of ohmic and non-ohmic conductors
Resistivity and its temperature dependence: ρ(T) = ρ₀[1 + α(T - T₀)]
Carbon resistor colour code
Resistors in series and parallel
EMF, terminal voltage, and internal resistance: V = ε - Ir
Cells in series and parallel combinations
Kirchhoff's junction rule (ΣI = 0) and loop rule (ΣV = 0)
Wheatstone bridge: balanced condition P/Q = R/S
Meter bridge: principle and experiment
Potentiometer: principle, comparing EMFs, finding internal resistance
out_of_scope: Detailed band theory of solids (covered in Semiconductor Electronics)
Superconductivity in detail (beyond NCERT scope)
AC circuits (covered in Theme T04)
Complex network analysis beyond Kirchhoff's rules

themes.theme_name: Magnetic Effects of Current and Magnetism

concepts.concept_name: Biot-Savart law and its application to current-carrying circular loop
Ampere's circuital law and its application to infinitely long straight wire, straight solenoid, and toroid
Force on a moving charge in magnetic and electric fields (Lorentz force), cyclotron
Force on a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field, force between two parallel current-carrying conductors, definition of ampere
Torque on a current loop in magnetic field, magnetic dipole moment, moving coil galvanometer and its conversion to ammeter and voltmeter

in_scope: Biot-Savart law: dB = (μ₀/4π)(Idl × r̂)/r²
Magnetic field at centre and on axis of a circular current loop
Ampere's circuital law: ∮B·dl = μ₀I_enclosed
Field due to infinite straight conductor: B = μ₀I/2πr
Magnetic field inside a solenoid: B = μ₀nI, and toroid: B = μ₀NI/2πr
Lorentz force: F = q(v × B) and F = q(E + v × B)
Motion of charged particle in uniform magnetic field: circular and helical paths
Cyclotron: principle, working, frequency, and limitations
Force on current-carrying conductor: F = Il × B
Force between parallel conductors: F/l = μ₀I₁I₂/2πd
Definition of ampere from force between parallel conductors
Torque on current loop: τ = NIAB sinθ = m × B
Moving coil galvanometer: principle, sensitivity, conversion to ammeter (shunt) and voltmeter (high resistance in series)
out_of_scope: Biot-Savart law applications to arbitrary shaped conductors (beyond NCERT examples)
Magnetic vector potential (university level)
Relativistic origin of magnetic force
Hall effect in detail (mentioned but not examinable at CBSE level)

concepts.concept_name: Bar magnet as an equivalent solenoid, magnetic field lines, magnetic dipole moment
Earth's magnetic field and magnetic elements: declination, dip, and horizontal component
Magnetic properties of materials: para-, dia-, and ferromagnetism; magnetic susceptibility and permeability; hysteresis

in_scope: Bar magnet: magnetic field lines, properties of field lines
Bar magnet as equivalent solenoid, magnetic dipole moment m = NIA
Torque on a magnetic dipole in uniform magnetic field: τ = m × B
Earth's magnetism: geographic and magnetic poles, magnetic meridian
Elements of Earth's magnetic field: declination (D), dip/inclination (I), horizontal component (B_H)
Relation: B_H = B cosI, B_V = B sinI
Magnetisation (M), magnetic intensity (H), susceptibility (χ), permeability (μ)
Classification: diamagnetic (χ < 0), paramagnetic (χ > 0 small), ferromagnetic (χ >> 1)
Curie's law and Curie temperature
Hysteresis loop: retentivity, coercivity, permanent magnets vs electromagnets
out_of_scope: Quantum mechanical explanation of magnetism (university level)
Magnetic domains in detail beyond basic description
Antiferromagnetism and ferrimagnetism (beyond NCERT scope)
Detailed geomagnetic field mapping

concepts.concept_name: Faraday's laws of electromagnetic induction, magnetic flux, and induced EMF
Lenz's law and conservation of energy, eddy currents and their applications
Motional EMF and its derivation, energy consideration
Self-inductance and mutual inductance, inductance of a solenoid, AC generator

in_scope: Magnetic flux: Φ = B·A = BA cosθ
Faraday's first law: change in flux induces EMF
Faraday's second law: ε = -dΦ/dt
Lenz's law: direction of induced current opposes the change
Eddy currents: origin, applications (electromagnetic braking, induction furnace), and minimisation
Motional EMF: ε = Blv for a rod moving in a magnetic field
Energy consideration in motional EMF
Self-inductance: ε = -L dI/dt, inductance of solenoid L = μ₀n²Al
Mutual inductance: ε₂ = -M dI₁/dt
Energy stored in an inductor: U = ½LI²
AC generator: principle, construction, working, EMF equation ε = NBAω sinωt
out_of_scope: Maxwell's equations in full form (only displacement current is introduced in T05)
Detailed design of commercial generators and motors
Coupled inductors and transformer theory in detail (covered in T04.02)
Inductance of non-solenoid geometries

concepts.concept_name: AC voltage and current: peak value, RMS value, and average value
AC circuit with pure resistor, pure inductor, and pure capacitor; phasor diagrams
Series LCR circuit, resonance, quality factor, and power in AC circuit (power factor)
Transformers: principle, working, step-up and step-down, energy losses

in_scope: Instantaneous, peak, RMS, and mean values of AC: V_rms = V₀/√2
AC through pure R: V and I in phase
AC through pure L: V leads I by π/2, inductive reactance X_L = ωL
AC through pure C: I leads V by π/2, capacitive reactance X_C = 1/ωC
Phasor diagrams for R, L, C, and combinations
Series LCR circuit: impedance Z = √(R² + (X_L - X_C)²)
Resonance: ω₀ = 1/√(LC), sharpness and Q-factor
Power in AC: P = V_rms I_rms cosφ, power factor cosφ = R/Z
Wattless current
Transformer: V_s/V_p = N_s/N_p = I_p/I_s (ideal), energy losses (copper, iron/eddy, flux leakage, hysteresis)
out_of_scope: Parallel LCR circuit analysis (beyond NCERT scope)
Complex impedance and j-notation (university level)
Three-phase AC circuits
Detailed transformer design and efficiency calculations

concepts.concept_name: Displacement current and Maxwell's equations (qualitative), need for displacement current
Electromagnetic waves: nature, characteristics, transverse nature, and speed of EM waves (c = 1/√(μ₀ε₀))
Electromagnetic spectrum: radio waves, microwaves, infrared, visible, ultraviolet, X-rays, gamma rays — their sources, detection, and uses

in_scope: Inconsistency of Ampere's circuital law, displacement current: I_d = ε₀ dΦ_E/dt
Modified Ampere's law with displacement current
Maxwell's equations (qualitative statement of all four)
EM wave: mutually perpendicular E and B oscillating in phase, transverse nature
Speed of EM waves: c = 1/√(μ₀ε₀) = E₀/B₀
Energy carried by EM waves, Poynting vector (qualitative)
EM spectrum: classification by frequency/wavelength
Properties, sources, detection, and applications of each band of EM spectrum
out_of_scope: Derivation of wave equation from Maxwell's equations (university level)
Poynting vector detailed derivation
Radiation pressure quantitative problems
Waveguides and antenna theory

concepts.concept_name: Reflection and refraction at plane and spherical surfaces, mirror formula, lens formula, and magnification
Total internal reflection: critical angle, applications (optical fibres, mirage)
Refraction through a prism: prism formula, minimum deviation, and dispersion of light
Lenses: thin lens formula, lens maker's formula, power of a lens, combination of thin lenses
Optical instruments: human eye, simple microscope, compound microscope, and astronomical telescope (reflecting and refracting) — magnifying power

in_scope: Laws of reflection and refraction (Snell's law: n₁ sinθ₁ = n₂ sinθ₂)
Refraction at spherical surfaces: n₂/v - n₁/u = (n₂ - n₁)/R
Mirror formula: 1/v + 1/u = 1/f, magnification m = -v/u
Total internal reflection: critical angle sinC = n₂/n₁ (n₂ < n₁)
Applications of TIR: optical fibres, mirage, brilliance of diamond
Prism: δ = (i₁ + i₂) - A, n = sin((A + D_m)/2)/sin(A/2)
Dispersion: angular dispersion, dispersive power
Thin lens formula: 1/v - 1/u = 1/f
Lens maker's formula: 1/f = (n - 1)(1/R₁ - 1/R₂)
Power of lens: P = 1/f (in dioptres), combination P = P₁ + P₂
Simple microscope: M = 1 + D/f
Compound microscope: M = m_o × m_e, normal and final image at D
Astronomical telescope (refracting): M = -f_o/f_e, normal adjustment and at D
Reflecting telescope: advantages over refracting
out_of_scope: Aberrations in detail (only qualitative mention)
Matrix methods in optics (university level)
Thick lens theory
Detailed design of cameras and projectors

concepts.concept_name: Huygens' principle: wavefront, refraction and reflection of plane waves using Huygens' principle
Interference: Young's double slit experiment, coherent sources, conditions for constructive and destructive interference, fringe width
Diffraction: single slit diffraction, width of central maximum
Polarisation: plane polarised light, Brewster's law, Malus's law, uses of polaroids

in_scope: Wavefront: spherical, cylindrical, and plane wavefronts
Huygens' principle: each point on wavefront is a source of secondary wavelets
Derivation of laws of reflection and refraction using Huygens' principle
Coherent and incoherent sources
Young's double slit experiment: fringe width β = λD/d
Conditions for maxima: d sinθ = nλ, minima: d sinθ = (n + ½)λ
Intensity distribution in interference pattern
Single slit diffraction: central maximum width 2λD/a, minima at a sinθ = nλ
Difference between interference and diffraction patterns
Polarisation by reflection (Brewster's law: tanθ_p = n), scattering, and double refraction
Malus's law: I = I₀ cos²θ
Uses of polaroids
out_of_scope: Multiple slit diffraction and diffraction grating quantitative treatment (beyond NCERT scope)
Fresnel diffraction (only Fraunhofer diffraction is in scope)
Elliptical and circular polarisation in detail
Fourier optics (university level)

topics.topic_name: Dual Nature of Radiation and Matter

concepts.concept_name: Photoelectric effect: experimental observations, effect of intensity, frequency, and potential on photoelectric current
Einstein's photoelectric equation: Kmax = hν - φ, threshold frequency, and stopping potential
Photon: energy E = hν, momentum p = h/λ, particle nature of light
Matter waves: de Broglie hypothesis λ = h/p = h/mv, Davisson-Germer experiment

in_scope: Hertz's and Lenard's observations on photoelectric effect
Laws of photoelectric emission
Effect of intensity: photoelectric current proportional to intensity
Effect of frequency: threshold frequency ν₀, no emission below ν₀
Stopping potential V₀ and maximum kinetic energy: eV₀ = Kmax
Einstein's photoelectric equation: Kmax = hν - φ₀
Work function φ₀ = hν₀
Photon properties: E = hν = hc/λ, p = hν/c = h/λ
de Broglie wavelength: λ = h/mv = h/p
de Broglie wavelength of electron accelerated through potential V: λ = h/√(2meV)
Davisson-Germer experiment: experimental verification of matter waves
out_of_scope: Compton effect (mentioned but not examinable at CBSE Class 12 level)
Wave packets and uncertainty principle in detail (qualitative only)
Electron microscope working in detail
Relativistic de Broglie wavelength

concepts.concept_name: Rutherford's alpha-particle scattering experiment: observations, nuclear model of atom, limitations
Bohr model of hydrogen atom: postulates, energy levels, radii of orbits
Hydrogen spectrum: spectral series (Lyman, Balmer, Paschen, Brackett, Pfund), line spectrum and energy level transitions

in_scope: Alpha-particle scattering: setup, observations (most pass through, few deflected, rare back-scattered)
Rutherford's nuclear model: small dense positive nucleus, electrons orbiting
Distance of closest approach: r₀ = (1/4πε₀)(2Ze²/Kα)
Impact parameter and scattering angle relation (qualitative)
Limitations of Rutherford model: electron radiation and spiral
Bohr's postulates: quantised orbits, angular momentum L = nh/2π, radiation during transitions
Radius of nth orbit: rₙ = n²a₀/Z where a₀ = 0.53 Å
Energy of nth level: Eₙ = -13.6Z²/n² eV
Hydrogen spectral series: 1/λ = R(1/n₁² - 1/n₂²)
Lyman (UV), Balmer (visible), Paschen (IR), Brackett (IR), Pfund (IR) series
Limitations of Bohr model
out_of_scope: Quantum mechanical model of atom (orbitals, quantum numbers in detail — covered in Chemistry)
Multi-electron atoms (Bohr model only for hydrogen-like atoms)
Sommerfeld's elliptical orbits (beyond NCERT scope)
Fine structure and hyperfine structure

concepts.concept_name: Composition of nucleus: atomic number, mass number, isotopes, isobars, isotones; nuclear size and density
Mass-energy relation E = mc², mass defect, and binding energy per nucleon curve
Radioactivity: alpha, beta, and gamma decay; radioactive decay law N = N₀e^(-λt), half-life, mean life
Nuclear fission and fusion: energy released, nuclear reactor (basic), stellar energy (proton-proton cycle and carbon cycle qualitative)

in_scope: Nucleus composition: protons (Z) and neutrons (N), A = Z + N
Isotopes, isobars, isotones with examples
Nuclear size: R = R₀A^(1/3) where R₀ ≈ 1.2 fm
Nuclear density is constant (~2.3 × 10¹⁷ kg/m³)
Mass defect: Δm = [Zm_p + (A-Z)m_n] - M
Binding energy: E_B = Δmc², binding energy per nucleon
BE/A curve: iron peak, implications for fission and fusion
Radioactive decay law: N = N₀e^(-λt), activity A = λN
Half-life: T½ = 0.693/λ, mean life τ = 1/λ
Alpha decay: ᴬ_ZX → ᴬ⁻⁴_(Z-2)Y + ⁴₂He
Beta minus decay: neutron → proton + electron + antineutrino
Gamma decay: de-excitation of nucleus
Nuclear fission: heavy nucleus splits, chain reaction, critical mass
Nuclear reactor: moderator, control rods, coolant (basic working)
Nuclear fusion: light nuclei combine, conditions (high temperature), stellar energy
out_of_scope: Shell model and liquid drop model in detail (university level)
Beta plus decay and electron capture in detail
Detailed nuclear reactor engineering
Particle physics: quarks, leptons, bosons (beyond NCERT scope)
Neutrino physics in detail

topics.topic_name: Semiconductor Electronics: Materials, Devices and Simple Circuits

concepts.concept_name: Energy bands in solids: conductors, semiconductors, and insulators; intrinsic and extrinsic semiconductors (n-type and p-type)
p-n junction: formation, depletion region, barrier potential; p-n junction diode: V-I characteristics, forward and reverse bias
Diode applications: rectifier (half-wave and full-wave), special purpose diodes (LED, photodiode, solar cell, Zener diode as voltage regulator)
Junction transistor: npn and pnp, transistor action, characteristics, transistor as switch and amplifier (common emitter configuration), voltage gain and current gain
Logic gates: OR, AND, NOT, NAND, NOR; truth tables and combination of gates

in_scope: Energy band theory: valence band, conduction band, forbidden gap
Classification based on band gap: metals (~0 eV), semiconductors (~1 eV), insulators (>3 eV)
Intrinsic semiconductor: pure Si/Ge, electron-hole pair generation, n_e = n_h = n_i
Extrinsic semiconductor: n-type (pentavalent dopant), p-type (trivalent dopant)
p-n junction formation: diffusion, drift, depletion region, barrier potential (~0.7 V Si, ~0.3 V Ge)
Forward bias: reduced barrier, current flows; Reverse bias: increased barrier, negligible current
V-I characteristics of p-n junction diode
Half-wave and full-wave rectifier circuits and output waveforms
Zener diode: breakdown voltage, V-I characteristics, as voltage regulator
LED: principle, materials, symbol
Photodiode: reverse bias operation, photocurrent, use in detection
Solar cell: principle, V-I characteristics, use in solar panels
npn and pnp transistor: structure, symbols, transistor action
Common emitter characteristics: input and output, α and β (current gains), β = α/(1-α)
Transistor as switch (cutoff and saturation) and as CE amplifier (voltage gain A_v = -βR_C/R_B)
Basic logic gates: OR, AND, NOT — truth tables and symbols
Universal gates: NAND, NOR — truth tables and realisation of basic gates using NAND/NOR
out_of_scope: Detailed semiconductor physics (Fermi level, carrier statistics — university level)
MOSFET and FET (beyond NCERT scope for CBSE Class 12)
Operational amplifiers (beyond NCERT scope)
Integrated circuit fabrication
Flip-flops, registers, and digital circuit design (beyond NCERT scope)
Communication systems chapter (removed from CBSE syllabus)
